alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for childcare costs
overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers providing childcare
title: Expenses and benefits: childcare

table.body:
As an employer providing childcare to your employees, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.

^Employer supported childcare is normally provided through [salary sacrifice.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/paye/payroll/special-pay/salary-sacrifice.htm "salary sacrifice"){:rel="external"} This means an employee gives up part of their salary in return for a non-cash benefit.^

##What's covered

What you have to pay and report depends on whether:

* you provide a workplace childcare facility yourself
* your employees pay for childcare themselves and you pay them back
* you contract directly with a childcare provider, such as a commercial nursery or a childminder
* you give your employees childcare vouchers
* your employees applied to join your employer supported childcare scheme on or after 6 April 2011

It also depends on whether the employee is a director, and how much they earn.
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You might not have to report anything to HMRC or pay tax and National Insurance.

##Workplace nurseries

If you provide places for employees' children in a workplace nursery, you don’t have to report or pay anything. To be exempt, a workplace nursery must:

* have the appropriate [registrations and approvals](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/EIM22003.htm "registrations and approvals"){:rel="external"}
* be available to all your employees
* provide childcare for your employees' children, or children they have parental responsibility for
* provide childcare up to the end of the week of 1 September following each child's 15th birthday, or 16th birthday for children with a disability

The facility doesn't have to be at your workplace. It can be in other premises that you manage and finance, as long as they're not a private residence.

##Commercial childcare or vouchers

You can provide a fixed amount of employee supported childcare to all employees without having to pay or report anything.

To be exempt, the childcare you provide (or provide vouchers for) needs to meet the criteria for workplace nurseries.

^Certain low-paid employees may be excluded from the requirement for childcare to be available to all employees. See HMRC's [technical guidance](/expenses-and-benefits-childcare/technical-guidance "technical guidace") on childcare voucher exemption.^

###Limits for exemption

For any employees who applied to join a childcare scheme you run before 6 April 2011, the limit is £55 a week, or £243 a month.

^There are different rules for employees who joined employer-supported childcare schemes on or after 6 April 2011.^

The main difference is that the limit for these employees depends on the rate of income tax they pay. The limits are shown in the following table:

Rate of income tax | Weekly exempt limit | Monthly exempt limit
-|-|-
Basic (20%) | £55 | £243
Higher (40%) | £28 | £124 
Additional (50%) | £22 | £97

You'll need to carry out a 'basic earnings assessment' to work out the correct rate, and keep certain records. See HMRC's guide to employer supported childcare for full details.

$D
[Download HMRC's guide to employer supported childcare (PDF, 67KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/thelibrary/employer-qa.pdf "Download HMRC's guide to employer supported childcare (PDF, 67KB)"){:rel="external"}
$D


###Commercial childcare for employees earning at a rate of less than £8,500 per year

You don't have to report or pay anything for these employees if you contract directly with a childcare provider, regardless of the cost of the childcare.

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: What's exempt

table.body:
If any of the childcare you provide isn't [exempt](/expenses-and-benefits-childcare/whats-exempt "exempt"), you may have to report the costs to HMRC, and you may have to deduct and pay tax and National Insurance on the cost to you.

##Commercial childcare

If you provide commercial childcare above the [exempt limit](/expenses-and-benefits-childcare/whats-exempt "exempt limit") to employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more per year, or directors, you need to: 

* fill in the amount above the limit on form P11D, section M
* pay Class 1A National Insurance on the amount above the limit

##Childcare vouchers

If you provide childcare vouchers to employees above the [exempt limit](/expenses-and-benefits-childcare/whats-exempt "exempt limit"), the following table shows what you'll need to report and pay.

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to deduct or pay
-|-|-
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of up to £8,500 | Fill in the amount above the limit on form P9D, section B | Deduct Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) on the cost to you of the vouchers
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more | Fill in the amount above the limit on form P11D, section C | Deduct Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) on the amount above the limit
Directors | Fill in the amount above the limit on form P11D, section C | Deduct Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) on the amount above the limit

##Childcare your employees pay for and you pay them back

If you cover the costs of employees' childcare in any of the following ways, this counts as earnings:

* paying them back for their childcare bills
* providing a cash allowance to cover childcare costs
* providing additional salary to meet the cost of childcare

In most cases, you'll need to:

* add the amount you pay the employee to their other earnings
* deduct and pay PAYE tax and Class 1 National Insurance through payroll

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]:Pay As You Earn
table.title: What to report and pay

table.body:
The amount you need to report depends on the kind of vouchers, and how you provide them.

##Commercial childcare or vouchers

The value to use is the cost of the childcare [above the exempt limit](/expenses-and-benefits-childcare/whats-exempt "above the exempt limit").

##Childcare your employees pay for and you pay them back

Use the amount that you pay the employee back for childcare costs.
